conclusion: Determine the initial acceleration of block A when it is pulled upward until block B just leaves the ground.
Two wooden blocks A and B are connected by a light spring.
When block B just leaves the ground, the normal force between block A and block B becomes zero.
The tension in the spring must be equal to the weight of block A.
The weight of block A is given by W_A = m_A * g.
The tension T in the spring is equal to the weight of block A: T = m_A * g.
When a constant force F is applied to block A, the net force on block A is F - T.
According to Newton's second law, the acceleration a of block A is given by F - T = m_A * a.
Substituting T = m_A * g into the equation, we get F - m_A * g = m_A * a.
Solving for a: a = (F - m_A * g) / m_A.
The magnitude of the initial acceleration of block A during this process is (F - m_A * g) / m_A.
